pullRequest.body:
- `TensorProduct.exists_multiset`, `TensorProduct.exists_finsupp_left`,
  `TensorProduct.exists_finsupp_right`, `TensorProduct.exists_finset`:
  any element of `M ⊗[R] N` can be written as a finite sum of pure tensors.
  See also `TensorProduct.span_tmul_eq_top`.

- `TensorProduct.exists_finite_submodule_left_of_finite`,
  `TensorProduct.exists_finite_submodule_right_of_finite`,
  `TensorProduct.exists_finite_submodule_of_finite` and 3 more:
  any finite subset of `M ⊗[R] N` is contained in `M' ⊗[R] N'`
  for some finitely generated submodules `M'` and `N'` of `M` and `N`, respectively.
  Each of these 3 functions has 2 variants.

---

nodes.body: LGTM. I'll wait if Riccardo wants to give it a look, and I'll maintainer-merge this tomorrow otherwise.

Sorry, I was a little busy. LGTM too, thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8678544804/job/23795662434)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8678544804/job/23795662380)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8678544804/job/23795662339)

```suggestion
open scoped TensorProduct
```
This breaks a couple of proofs, but it is enough to start them with `classical`.
Do we really want 8 versions of this result? I understand that finding a single canonical one is probably not possible, but 8 seems really a lot.

I think 
```lean
example (s : Set (M ⊗[R] N)) (hs : s.Finite) : 
    ∃ (M' : Submodule R M) (N' : Submodule R N), M'.FG ∧ N'.FG ∧
      s ⊆ LinearMap.range (mapIncl M' N')
```
is enough?

Then use `f.support.image f` for `Finsupp`s, `Set.Finite.ofFinset` for `Finset`s,  `Set.finite_range` for functions from `Fintype`s, `{x, y}` for pairs etc. And I don't think there is need for left and right versions.

Also I don't think the lemmas above are necessary. Usually when you find yourself writing tensors as a sum of pure tensors in lean, it is usually better done directly using induction.
```lean
import Mathlib

variable {R M N : Type*}

variable [CommSemiring R] [AddCommMonoid M] [AddCommMonoid N] [Module R M] [Module R N]

variable {M₁ : Submodule R M} {N₁ : Submodule R N}

open TensorProduct Submodule

lemma TensorProduct.range_mapIncl (M' : Submodule R M) (N' : Submodule R N) :
    LinearMap.range (mapIncl M' N') = span R (Set.image2 (· ⊗ₜ ·) M' N') := by
  rw [mapIncl, map_range_eq_span_tmul]
  congr; ext; simp

lemma TensorProduct.range_mapIncl_mono
    {M₁' M₂' : Submodule R M} {N₁' N₂' : Submodule R N}
    (hM : M₁' ≤ M₂') (hN : N₁' ≤ N₂') :
    LinearMap.range (mapIncl M₁' N₁') ≤ LinearMap.range (mapIncl M₂' N₂') := by
  rw [range_mapIncl, range_mapIncl]
  exact span_mono (Set.image2_subset (SetLike.le_def.mp hM) (SetLike.le_def.mp hN))

example (s : Set (M ⊗[R] N)) (hs : s.Finite) : 
    ∃ (M' : Submodule R M) (N' : Submodule R N), M'.FG ∧ N'.FG ∧
      s ⊆ LinearMap.range (mapIncl M' N') := by
  refine hs.induction_on ?_ ?_
  · exact ⟨_, _, fg_bot, fg_bot, Set.empty_subset _⟩
  rintro a s - - ⟨M', N', hM', hN', h⟩
  induction' a using TensorProduct.induction_on with x y x y hx hy
  · exact ⟨M', N', hM', hN', Set.insert_subset (zero_mem _) h⟩
  · refine ⟨_, _, hM'.sup (fg_span_singleton x),
      hN'.sup (fg_span_singleton y), Set.insert_subset ?_ ?_⟩
    · exact ⟨⟨x, mem_sup_right (mem_span_singleton_self x)⟩ ⊗ₜ
        ⟨y, mem_sup_right (mem_span_singleton_self y)⟩, rfl⟩
    · exact fun z hz ↦ range_mapIncl_mono le_sup_left le_sup_left (h hz)
  · obtain ⟨M₁', N₁', hM₁', hN₁', h₁⟩ := hx
    obtain ⟨M₂', N₂', hM₂', hN₂', h₂⟩ := hy
    refine ⟨_, _, hM₁'.sup hM₂', hN₁'.sup hN₂', Set.insert_subset (add_mem ?_ ?_) ?_⟩
    · exact range_mapIncl_mono le_sup_left le_sup_left (h₁ (Set.mem_insert x s))
    · exact range_mapIncl_mono le_sup_right le_sup_right (h₂ (Set.mem_insert y s))
    · exact fun z hz ↦ range_mapIncl_mono le_sup_left le_sup_left
        (h₁ (Set.subset_insert x s hz))
```

> Do we really want 8 versions of this result? I understand that finding a single canonical one is probably not possible, but 8 seems really a lot.

Let me see. Currently there are the following combinations:

- submodules: left, right or both
- M and N are types with module structure, or they are already submodules
- fintype, finsupp, pair, or only one element. From the proof I think the latter two cases can be removed. Also the finsupp case is a possible variation, but it's never used yet.

In fact what I really need is `exists_finite_submodule_left_of_pair'` and `exists_finite_submodule_right_of_pair'`, used in https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/2d07f5a79f80dd8d4371b2bc02267ec03b3c88c5/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/LinearDisjoint.lean#L483-L502

OK, now there are only 6 results of `exists_finite_submodule`. Adapted the proof of @erdOne. Please give some comments.

> And I don't think there is need for left and right versions.

Unfortunately I need to use them in linear disjoint file... However now left and right versions are corollaries of the both version.

Also the `exists_multiset`, etc. are not removed yet. I think they *may be* useful by someone...

I originally thought that the `LinearMap.range_comp_le_range` part could be performed inline at the application site and there is no need for separate lemmas concerning left and right. But as long as the number of lemmas does not overwhelm the user, we might as well provide them for convenience.
This should go under the definition of `mapIncl`.
